The Related Discourses

13. The Noble Path

6. Deathlessness

Thus have I heard:1 One time, the Buddha stayed in the kingdom of Śrāvastī at Anāthapiṇḍada Park in Jeta Grove.

There was a monk then named Ariṣṭa who went to the Buddha, prostrated at his feet, and withdrew to sit at one side. He asked, “Bhagavān, there’s what’s called ‘deathlessness.’2 What is called ‘deathlessness’?”

The Buddha told Ariṣṭa, “Deathlessness is a description of an element, but I take it to be the end of the contaminants. That’s a clear explanation of this name.”

The monk Ariṣṭa asked the Buddha, “Bhagavān, isn’t there a path and steps that attain deathlessness when they are cultivated and cultivated often?”

The Buddha told the monk, “There is. It’s known as the noble eightfold path, which is right view up to right concentration.”

After the Buddha had taught this discourse, the monks who heard what the Buddha had taught rejoiced and handed it down.

Endnotes

  1. The Pali parallel is SN 45.7. The Pali sutta is only partially parallel, containing a question about the “deathless” and equating it with the end of desire, anger, and delusion.
  2. The Chinese translates amṛta as ‘sweet dew’ 甘露, which was a mythical substance considered to be parallel to the Indian concept of ambrosia, which was the food of the gods that gave them their immortality.
Translator: Charles Patton
